title: DOOR DAMAGE CLASSIFICATION
question: What document outlines the standard repair procedures for bonded doors?
answer:
IMPORTANT NOTICE: All checkup timelines, replacement periods, major service intervals, the inspection procedure, operational limits, usage cycles, etc., set by Cessna are solely based on the use of new, remanufactured, or overhauled Cessna-certified components. If parts are designed, manufactured, remanufactured, overhauled, purchased, and/or approved by non-Cessna organizations, then the data in Cessna’s maintenance/service manuals and parts catalogs do not apply and the purchaser is warned not to rely on such data for non-Cessna parts. All checkup timelines, replacement periods, major service intervals, the inspection procedure, operational limits, usage cycles, etc., for such non-Cessna parts must be obtained from the supplier or maker of such non-Cessna parts.

DOOR DAMAGE CLASSIFICATION
1.
Repairable Damage
A.
Bonded doors may be repaired by the same methods used for riveted structure.
Rivets are a
satisfactory substitute for bonded seams on these assemblies. The strength of the bonded seams in
doors may be replaced by a single 3/32, 2117-AD rivet per running inch of bond seam. The standard
repair procedures outlined in AC43.13-1b are also applicable to bonded doors.

All checkup timelines, part replacement schedules, overhaul cycles, the check method, lifespan thresholds, rotation limits, etc., for such non-Cessna parts must be obtained from the vendor or originator of such non-Cessna parts.

DOOR DAMAGE CLASSIFICATION
1.
Repairable Damage
A.
Bonded doors may be repaired by the same methods used for riveted structure.
Rivets are a
satisfactory substitute for bonded seams on these assemblies. The strength of the bonded seams in
doors may be replaced by a single 3/32, 2117-AD rivet per running inch of bond seam. The standard
repair procedures outlined in AC43.13-1b are also applicable to bonded doors.
